text: uh cross-platform application development framework uh i started contributing to a platform about four
years ago when it was open sourced and i contributed
contributed as an open source contributor for a while and then became like a more stable part of the core team
that develops the platform itself so this will be a kind of introduction to
see what umo platform can do and how it can help you build applications that run everywhere
so i will first start with oh let's just okay so let's start with the problem
itself where you want to build applications that run everywhere on all platforms and you have multiple
platforms that users actually use so there is windows there is mac os
all apple users have also ios devices like iphones and ipads people have androids and some of them
have linuxes on their pcs and there are also many people who are
using the web so to reach all of these people you would need to build multiple different
applications and for each of those platforms you need a specific way of
coding so for windows you're building c-sharp xaml applications on mac os you would be
building app kit based swift applications on linux you would be
building whatever on linux is uh on ios you would build you will be bringing in
a ios swift and swift ui and android would be
building in kotlin and axml and in the website of things you would be building
in some crazy javascript framework and using html css to style it all so it's a wide
range of technologies and not a single developer can cover them all so
what can we do to improve upon that [Music] the first step would be to share some
code and of course people have been successful with this by sharing code with javascript even with c-sharp you
can use xamarin forms or as it's going to be called in the future maui to share
both business logic and ui layer of the application uh but the problem is for example with
maui is that you can reach mobile users and desktop users but you cannot reach
the browsers that means chrome firefox safari and so
on so if you need to reach website users as well you would have to build a separate application using blazer or
something like that so the solution would be even better solution would be to have a
single platform that can cover all the needs
of you as a developer and all the targets that you want to support and in this
case the solution comes in the form of having one single code base written in c
sharp as the ubiquitous.net language and xaml as the ui layer language
if you have built windows applications before which is windows presentation foundation
universal windows platform or now in ui you definitely know xaml as the language
that's used in microsoft technologies to build uis and xamarin forms also has xaml code
even though the xaml in xamarin forms is kind of a different and kind of simplified version of xaml because
they're rendering their user controls using native controls underneath so for
example a button in android in android is a android widget button
on ios it's ui button and on windows it's a xaml button so
this means that you have like your ui is composed of a single common denominator
between all of those platforms and to introduce some company branding or styling and improving the looks of
the application you need to reach into those native apis which might not be the
ideal solution for you so the solution the even better solution
comes in the form of uno platform which is a pixel perfect solution that allows you to completely style your application
to look exactly the same on all targets and you do that by writing a single code
base that you just take and compile on all targets and it works
the goal of uno platform is that you can write your application as a windows
application use your existing skills so just use the
same apis that you can find on windows and then compile it against uno platform
to reach android ios web assembly linux and mac os
the trick uno platform uses is that its namespaces are exactly the
same as bin ui namespaces which is the windows ui library so as you can see on on the slide
in vinui you can find a button in the namespace microsoft ui xaml controls button and in uno platform we have it
exactly in the same place so microsoft vr example controls button the same for border and the same for all
the other controls and apis that are in envin ui
so when you take your code base that's written for windows and compile it
uh using uno platform for android ios mac os assembly linux it will just work
without any code changes because the surface of the api is exactly the same
and in ideal situation your application will just work without any code changes
as for the ui the ui layer is rendered using native rendering capabilities of each of the
platforms so on windows we're just using windows apis there is no uno platform involved
there it's just running against directly against the metal but on the other platforms we're using
the rendering capabilities on that platform so for example ios is using
core graphics to render the chrome of controls or backgrounds or borders and so on
uh on air on macos we're using app kit and core graphics to do the same on android
it's using android views and the native rendering capabilities on android
on the web it's using html and css and on linux that's the special one
we're using scarp to render the ui but you as a developer are only
knowing about the xaml code you just write the xaml code and the rest is handled for you by uno platform
and without further ado i will show you a first example of
a platform application action so i will open visual studio

this extension gives you access to uno platform solution templates which is

are four different templates that are pre-installed first one is multi-platform app

multi-platform application.6 and the difference between these two
is that the xamarin one is the one that's stable the dotnet six one is
for the future support of dotnet 6 mobile which is android ios and
net6 version of mini ui but it's not stable enough so i don't

infrastructure below uh xamarin or i mean dot net 6 mobile
uh and it's still not stable and they are changing with each release of visual studio and we as uno platform are
depending on that same infrastructure so we need to catch up with each release and update our templates to actually
work with with what they are doing so
until maui is stably released which hopefully should be
this year at build i recommend you to start with the xamarin template which is more stable
and more reliable and next up there is also crossbar from ui
test library which allows you to create a project that allows you to test your
application using ui tests and that allows you to build cross-platform tests
that run on android ios and web assembly so you can have your application fully
ui tested and verify that everything works and you don't bring any regressions when you do changes in the
future we actually use this very extensively as part of our code base so
with each each commit to master we run a very extensive set of ui tests as well as
runtime tests that verify that we didn't break anything and that's very important because it saved us a million times
already when we introduced a new feature which accidentally broke something else
in the platform and that was not really pleasant so ui tests are really great
and finally there is also multi-platform library and this template
allows you to build reusable template reusable libraries for uno platform applications so if you build something
that you want to reuse across multiple different projects you can put it in this multi-platform library and then
